context: Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede;°
Thise olde folk can muchel thing,”° quod she.
Ful many a noble wif, and many a maide,°
Which is a strange thing to° thy persone.
And therfor, leve° housbond, I thus conclude
He that coveiteth is a poure wight
And be to yow a trewe° humble wif
And be to yow a trewe° humble wif
I put me in your wise governance;
Ben quike again, that winter dede made
“Now uncle dere,” quod she, “tel it us
Lat be to me your fremde maner speche
And seide, “Gladly, leve nece dere
The goode, wise, worthy, fresshe, and free
This other day, nought gon ful longe while
Ledest the fin, by juste purveiaunce
“O mercy, dere nece,” anoon quod he
That to biholde it was a noble game
“And eek I knowe, of longe time agoon
That he may make avaunt, by juste cause;
In March, that chaungeth ofte time his face
For evere som mistrust, or nice strif
Our wreche is this, our owene wo to drinke.
“How ofte time hath it yknowen be
And othere of hir wommen, a grete route
Ben humble subgit, trewe in min entente
And spreden on hir kinde cours by rowe;
In grete disese abideth for the peine.”
And in ful humble wise, as in his speche
“Now, goode nece, be it never so lite
Lat be your nice shame and your folie
Which hadde his lord and grete freend ben ay;
For which with sobre chere hir herte lough;
“And eek, for she is straunge, he wol forbere
Eleine in al hir goodly softe wise
Now faire brother, beth al hool, I preie!”
And other swiche, dere ynough a leek°
In lerning of this elvish° nice° lore
And this chanon him thanked ofte sithe,°
Stinketh, as witnessen thise olde wise;°
An holwe° stikke (tak kepe° and be war!)
Now, goode sir, go forth thy wey and hy the.”°

context: Ne shal no° trewe lover come in helle.
And many another noble worthy dede
And tendre flesh,° and make his couche° of silk
Ne never so trewe,° ne so debonaire.°
And a povre wenche,° other than this—
And for that other is a povre womman
And, God it woot,° min owene dere brother
Now shaltow, false theef, thy song forgon,°
Ne never swete noise shul ye make
My son, ful ofte, for° to muche speche
For he so yong and tendre was of age;
That in an aley° hadde a privee place;
He putte it in our owne jugement.
And everich hath of God a propre yifte,°
Ye been a noble prechour in this cas!
A wise wif, if that she can hir good,°
¶“ ‘Sir olde kainard,° is this thin array?
Sir olde lechour, lat thy japes° be!
To wedde a povre womman, for costage;°
Til they be wedded; olde dotard shrewe!
And clep° me “faire dame” in every place;
For certein, olde dotard, by your leve,°
Thou liknest it also to wilde fir;
Ful giltelees, by Goddes swete pine!°
¶“Than wolde I seye, ‘Goode lief,° taak keep°
And han a sweete spiced° conscience
But I wol kepe it for your owne tooth.°
Whan I had dronke a draughte of sweete win.
In this matere a queinte° fantasie;
Greet prees° at market maketh dere ware,°
And also in another privee place.
How pore he was, ne eek of what degree.°
And me of olde Roman gestes° teche
‘O! hastow slain me, false theef?’° I seide
And seide, ‘deere suster Alisoun
And that he seid, ‘Min owne trewe° wif
In hevene and helle, in erthe and salte see
As man, brid, best, fishe, herbe and grene tree
“Ye, swete herte? allas, I may nought rise
With look doun cast and humble yolden chere
Was, twyes, “Mercy, mercy, swete herte!”
Quod Troilus, “O goodly fresshe free!
And I to ben your verray humble trewe
Lo, this mene I, min owene swete herte.”
And gan to speken in a sobre wise
But gode brother, do now as thee oughte
To holden secree swich an heigh matere;
For wel wot I, in wise folk, that vice
“But now to purpos; leve brother dere
For at thy day thou shalt me trewe finde.
That han in winter dede been and dreie
“But goode nece, if I mighte ever plese
Criseyde, whiche that coude as muche good
And seide, “Lord, this is an huge rain!
And Pandarus, with a ful sobre chere
And him hir ‘leef ’ and ‘dere herte’ calle
Ye knowe eek how it is your owne knight
And eek so lik a sooth, at prime face
Now doth him sitte, gode nece dere
Your grete trouthe, and servise every day
And after winter folweth grene May.
And al foryaf, and ofte time him keste.
Have mercy, swete herte min, Criseyde!
Foryeve it me, min owene swete herte.”
Ful bittre drink; and for to han gladnesse
As she that juste cause hadde him to triste
Min herte swete, how I yow mighte plese!
For certes, fresshe wommanliche wif
Awey, thou foule daunger and thou fere
And fallen in a newe joye anoon
With herte sore, to Troilus thus seide:—
That I, your humble servaunt and your knight
And seide, “Freend, as I am trewe knight
But now I fele a newe qualitee
He coude° hunte at° wilde deer
Therinne° is many a wilde best
That he fond, in a privee° woon,°
Forthi be glad, min owene dere brother
And upon newe cas lith newe avis.
It lith not in my power, leve brother.
Now is not this a nice vanitee?
Shul blake been, in tokening, herte swete
How shal your tendre herte this sustene?
Unto Criseyde, in a ful secree wise
Aboute hir eyen two a purpre ring
And nought encresse, leve nece swete;
But that free chois is yeven us everichoon.
We have no free chois, as these clerkes rede.
That han hir top ful heighe and smothe yshore;
For to destroye our free chois every del.—
As bittre weren, out of teres kinde
But ofte time hir colde mouth he kiste;
“And that shal been an huge quantitee
And that hir herte trewe was and kinde
That of hir heste he might hir trewe finde.
Dwel rather here, min owene swete herte!
“For which, with humble, trewe, and pitous herte
That, though we comen in our bare sherte
A riche gnof,° that gestes heeld to bord,°
Of derne° love he coude and of° solas;°
And lik a maiden meke for to see.
For derne° love of thee, lemman,° I spille.”°
“Now, dere lady, if thy wille be
And broghte of mighty ale a large quart;
For it is Goddes owne heste° dere.
Go, dere spouse, and help to save our lif.”
That trewe love was ever so ivel biset!°
Lemman, thy grace, and swete brid, thin ore!”°
A softe paas he wente over the street
“What, Absolon! for Cristes swete tree,°
Thou sholdest have, as I am trewe smith;
“Spek, swete brid,° I noot° nat wher thou art.”
Ful many a riche contree hadde he wonne;
I have, God woot,° a large feeld to ere,°
And waike° been the oxen in my plough.
And swoor his ooth, as he was trewe knight
Nat fully quike,° ne fully dede they were
Nat fully quike,° ne fully dede they were
And soothly,° leve brother, this is al.
That many a trewe man hath doon mescheef,°
Encresen double wise the peines stronge
So muche sorwe had never creature
That lene° he wex,° and drie as is a shaft.°
And cladde him as a povre laborer
Who feleth double soor and hevinesse
Welcome be thou, faire fresshe May
Welcome be thou, faire fresshe May
A longe time; and after he up sterte.
And seide: “Arcite, false traitour wikke,°
Bothe suffisaunt and mete° to darreine°
Youre owne mouth, by your confessioun
Can° hem therfor as muche thank as me;
That swich a noble theatre° as it was
An oratorie riche for to see
Hath Theseus don wroght° in noble wise.
In gaude° grene hir statue clothed was
A wrethe° of gold arm-greet,° of huge wighte,°
Ful many a tame leoun and lepart.°
And doun he kneleth, and with humble chere°
Ne renoun° in this cas, ne veine glorie
Chaste goddesse, wel wostow° that I
That al hir hote love, and hir desir
Bihold, goddesse of clene° chastitee
Of faire yonge fresshe Venus free,°
Of faire yonge fresshe Venus free,°
I wol be trewe juge, and no partie.°
Of olde folk, and folk of tendre yeres
He leide him bare the visage° on the bere
And than with grene wode and spicerie
Ne how the Grekes with an huge route°
That gentil Palamon, your owne knight
And, though° he were a povre bacheler,°
Ful ofte time he had the bord bigonne
His hors were goode but he was nat gay
And al was conscience and tendre herte
Ful many a deintee hors hadde he in stable
Unto his ordre he was a noble post
Of double worsted was his semicope
As lene was his hors as is a rake
Al was fee simple to him in effect
He rood but hoomly in a medlee cote
For he was Epicurus owne sone
Ful ofte time he was knight of the shire
Of nice conscience took he no keep
Hir frendshipe nas nat newe to biginne
She hadde passed many a straunge strem
And was a povre Parson of a toun
But riche he was of holy thoght and werk
A shiten shepherde and a clene sheep
A trewe swinkere and a good was he
For Cristes sake for every povre wight
He was shortsholdred brood a thikke knarre
Ful longe were his legges and ful lene
A povre person dwelling upon lond
A large man he was with eyen stepe
Our counseil was nat longe for to seche
For whan they came from any strange place
That shal be sent to strange nacioun
I, wrecche womman, no fors° though I spille.°
Nas° herd swich tendre weping for pitee
To shippe is brought this woful faire maide
Gret was the prees,° and riche was th’array
A softe pas° solempnely they ride.
Thurghout our wilde see, til, atte laste
And Custance hath so longe sojourned there
Fro false blame, and thou, merciful maide,°
And Custance, with a deedly pale face
Thou glorie of wommanhede, thou faire may,°
Thou haven° of refut,° brighte sterre° of day
O mercy, dere constable!” quod she;
Habundantly for hir, ful longe space
And longe time dwelled she in that place
“Fader,” quod she, “your yonge child Custance
Now, Gode fader, mercy I yow crie
Not longe time to endure
That clerkes° had, in olde time
Hom, for it was a longe terme.
¶“A mercy, swete ladi dere!”
It were to longe for to dwelle;
I wol do peint° with pure golde
With many gladde° gilde° stremes;
Blew, bright, clere was the aire
Fro al the hounds a prive° way.
And leide al smothe° doun his heres.°
Doun by a floury grene went°
To an oke,° an huge tree.
The blood was fled, for pure drede,°
“Graunt mercy, goode frend,” quod he
That is a false flatering beste;
Was false whiche° a fool she was!
As a white walle or a table;
So noble porte and meintenaunce.°
Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
It was hir owne pure lokinge
She nas to sobre° ne to glad;
But goode folk, over al other
¶“And which° a goodly softe speche
Semed a rounde toure of ivoire,°
¶“And goode faire White she hete,°
¶“And goode faire White she hete,°
I was right yonge, soth to say
Noght longe time, leve° hit wel.
And ofte time I songe hem loude;
So moche beaute, trewely
In my tale, for pure fere
Softe° and quaking for pure drede
For pure fear, but stale away;
By Seint Johan! on a riche hille
Whan she forgoth hir owene swete herte?
With hauke on hond, and with an huge route
Shal been your fresshe wommanliche face
Although ful pale ywaxen was the mone;
My swerd, min helm, and, leve brother dere
“But sin of fine force I moot arise
That deintee was, al coste it greet richesse
The lettres eek, that she of olde time
And seide, “Leve brother Pandarus
For which with chaunged deedlich pale face
‘Now goode swete, love me wel, I preye.’
With softe vois he, of his lady dere
Ful pale ywaxen was hir brighte face
For wise folk in bokes it expresse
With sterne vois and mighty limes square
Criseyde mene was of hir stature
She sobre was, eek simple, and wis withal
Yong, fresshe, strong, and hardy as lioun;
And he was ethe ynough to maken dwelle.
And after this, withouten longe lette
“What wene ye your wise fader wolde
Inwith hir fadres faire brighte tente.
That she him yaf the faire baye stede
Almost, ywis, al newe was my care.
Which that men clepeth wode Jalousie
And feble, that he walketh by potente;
That in a forest faste he welk to wepe
The blisful goddes, through hir grete might
What newe lust, what beaute, what science
What wratthe of juste cause have ye to me?
I fele now so sharpe a newe peine
Me recomaunde unto your noble grace.
As ye wel knowe how longe time agoon
Foryeve it me, min owene swete herte.
“Ywis, min owene dere herte trewe
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
And ofte time he was in purpos grete
To hir he wroot yet ofte time al newe
To feffe with your newe love,” quod he
But trewely, Criseyde, swete may
Of Troilus, this ilke noble knight
And ofte time, I finde that they mette
Through false folk; God yeve hem sorwe, amen!
That with hir grete wit and subtiltee
Lo here, the forme of olde clerkes speche
Upon a river, in a grene mede,°
Of newe flaume; and wel aspied I thenne
And in a privee corner, in disporte,°
The wise and worthy, secree,° trewe as stel
Right as the fresshe, rede rose newe
A yeer is not so longe to endure
Of yonge folk, that haunteden° folie
To gete a glotoun deintee° mete° and drinke!
And false swering is yet more reprevable.°
Of heighe Goddes hestes° honurable
Ther cam a privee° theef, men clepeth° Deeth
An old man and a povre° with hem mette.
As longe time as° it is Goddes wille.
And seye, ‘Leve° moder,° leet me in!
That in my chambre longe time hath be
To sleen us yonge folk, thou false theef!”°
To sleen us yonge folk, thou false theef!”°
And for our owene tresor doon us honge.°
And pleye at dees right at our owene wille.”
The thridde° he kepte clene for his drinke.
¶A wif he hadde, ycomen of noble kin;
In cradel it lay and was a propre page.°
And straunge° he made it of° hir mariage.
¶Than were ther yonge povre scolers two
Ful pale he was for dronken,° and nat reed.
A wilde fir° upon thair bodies falle!°
And seide, “Far wel, Malin, swete wight!°
“Now dere lemman,”° quod she, “go, far wel!
And, goode lemman, God thee save and kepe!”°
For Cristes saule,° and heer a noble game.
¶“Ye, false harlot,”° quod the millere, “hast?
A! false traitour! false clerk!” quod he
For she was falle aslepe a lite wight°
¶A povre widwe, somdel° stape° in age
Was whilom° dwelling in a narwe° cotage
In pacience ladde a ful simple lif
No deintee° morsel passed thurgh hir throte;
With stikkes, and a drie dich withoute
Was cleped° faire damisel° Pertelote.
Of youre rede colera,° pardee
Now help me, dere brother, er I die;
Of o° thing God hath sent me large grace;°
For whan I fele anight° your softe side
False dissimilour,° O Greek Sinon
(Nedely clepe° I simple necessitee);
Or elles, if free chois be graunted me
¶O Gaufred,° dere maister soverain,°
As though I were hir owne brother dere.
And she him thonked with ful humble chere
With newe grene, of lusty Ver the prime
And swote smellen floures white and rede
O verrey foles! nice and blinde be ye;
So ferde it by this fers and proude knight;
Ye wise, proude, and worthy folkes alle
Yelt bittre fruit, though swete seed be sowe.
Yelt bittre fruit, though swete seed be sowe.
Into hir hond, and with ful humble chere
O mercy, dere herte, and help me from
As I best can, gon sithen longe while.
What! many a man hath love ful dere ybought
And som, thou seidest, hadde a blaunche fevere
And some han feined ofte time, and tolde
Be lusty, free, persevere in thy servise
For this have I herd seide of wise ylered
With sobre chere, although his herte pleide
Dede were his japes and his crueltee
